title: The Architecture of Complexity
summary: Simon's 1962 paper 'The Architecture of Complexity' establishes near-decomposability as a fundamental principle of complex system organization. The paper argues that complex systems evolve more rapidly when they can be decomposed into semi-independent subsystems with strong internal interactions and weak inter-subsystem coupling. Simon uses examples from watchmaking, biological cells, social organizations, and computer systems to demonstrate that hierarchical organization with near-decomposability is not just common but necessary for evolvable complexity. The paper introduces the parable of two watchmakers (Tempus and Hora) to illustrate how hierarchical assembly dramatically outperforms flat assembly in the presence of interruptions.
smoc_relevance_summary: This paper provides the theoretical foundation for SMoC's LAYERS and SCALES architecture. Simon's near-decomposability principle explains why good code is layered: each layer is nearly decomposable from others (loose coupling) while maintaining strong internal cohesion. The 16-level scale hierarchy in SMoC implements Simon's insight—each scale (Function, Module, Application) can be analyzed semi-independently because changes at one scale don't immediately propagate to all others. Simon's watchmaker parable directly applies to refactoring: monolithic code is like Tempus's watch (one interruption destroys all progress), while modular code is like Hora's (each module preserves progress). The paper also grounds SMoC's emphasis on bounded rationality—architects can only reason about complex systems because near-decomposability limits the scope of analysis needed.

key_smoc_concepts.mapping: Simon argues complex systems organize into hierarchies of subsystems, each level having characteristic time scales and interaction strengths. In SMoC's 16 scales, each level (Line, Function, File, Module...) operates at different time scales (lines change frequently, architectures change slowly) and has characteristic coupling (lines within functions are tightly coupled, modules are loosely coupled). Simon's principle: analyze at the right scale for the question asked.
quotes_or_pages: p.468: 'Hierarchic systems have a property...near decomposability'
p.473: 'The time required for a complex system to evolve...depends critically on the numbers and distribution of potential intermediate stable forms'

key_smoc_concepts.mapping: Simon defines near-decomposability: subsystems interact weakly compared to internal component interactions. In SMoC, architectural layers (Presentation, Domain, Infrastructure) are nearly decomposable—changes in Presentation rarely affect Domain logic because coupling is minimized. Simon proves this organization enables faster evolution and more robust maintenance. SMoC's layer enforcement (dependency direction rules) operationalizes near-decomposability.
quotes_or_pages: p.474: 'In a nearly decomposable system, the short-run behavior of each component is approximately independent'
p.477: 'Near decomposability also permits...replacing or modifying components'

key_smoc_concepts.mapping: Simon argues that architects cannot analyze all interactions in complex systems—near-decomposability makes analysis tractable by limiting the scope of necessary reasoning. In SMoC, this justifies local analysis (analyzing one module without loading entire codebase into context). The principle: good architecture respects cognitive limits, bad architecture exceeds them.
quotes_or_pages: p.467: 'The central task of a natural science is to make the wonderful commonplace'
p.481: 'Most complex systems...can be analyzed and understood as hierarchies'

gaps_or_extensions: Simon focuses on biological and social systems. SMoC extends to software with specific scales, formal metrics for decomposability (coupling/cohesion), and operationalization via Collider analysis that computes near-decomposability quantitatively.
